summary: coronaviruses are large, enveloped viruses with single-stranded, positive-sense, non-segmented RNA genomes. betacoronaviruses can be further subdivided into four phylogenetic groups. emergence of severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus (SARS-CoV) generated considerable interest in the biodiversity, genomics, evolution, natural hosts and potential inter-species transmission of coronaviruses. 118 rectal swab samples from Rousettus leschenaulti bats sampled in china were screened for the presence of coronavirus RNA. of these, 47 (40%) samples were found to be coronavirus positive. however, our attempts to isolate the virus using a number of cell lines were unsuccessful. sequence of the RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RdRp) gene indicated that the newly identified virus was likely to be a novel coronavirus according to previously proposed criteria. the virus was tentatively designated as Rousettus bat coronavirus GCCDC1. Ro-BatCoV GCCDC1 was most closely related to Ro-BatCoV HKU9 strains [18] with 66.6% - 67.4% nucleotide identities. a small intact ORF with 276 bases embedded between the N and NS7a genes was the most striking feature of the genome. the p10 protein was encoded by the first ORF of segment S1 of avian and bat fusogenic orthoreoviruses [20], which are double-stranded segmented RNA viruses belonging to the family Reoviridae. this ORF was provisionally marked as p10 according to the molar weight of protein that it encoded. GAACTGTG 4 M 25914–26579 221 75.6–80.5 43.2 42.3–42.7 41.1 41.1 43.6 TCTAACGAACAGGA 27 N 26627–27958 443 68.0–71.7 39.1 39.5–40.0 41.7 41.4–41.7 38.4–38.7 GGAAACGAACCTAT 5 p10 j 27994–29269 91 NA NA NA AATGACAAACCCAA gene is specific to Ro-BatCoV GCCDC1, there are no homologous genes in the genomes of Ro-BatCoV HKU9, SARS-CoV, BatCoV HKU3 strains, MERS-CoV, BatCoV HKU4 strains and BatCoV HKU5 strains. there is no comparability of ORFs in this region. the putative leader and body transcription regulatory sequences were predicted in accordance with consensus core sequences of the TRSs of betacoronaviruses. the TRS core sequence, 5’-ACGAAC-3’, was consistent with those of SARS-CoV, Ro-BatCoV HKU9 and other betacoronaviruses. in the putative TRS of the p10 gene, there was one nucleobase difference with the consensus core sequence. a similar phenomenon may occur at the cleavage site between NSP10 and NSP12 of Ro-BatCoV GCCDC1. a similar phenomenon may occur at the cleavage site between NSP10 and NSP12 of Ro-BatCoV GCCDC1 where the CAG codon has mutated to CAC. seven conserved replicase domains of Ro-BatCoV GCCDC1 were selected for analysis. the amino acid identities of seven concatenated domains revealed they shared 84.4% - 84.8% identity with those of Ro-BatCoV HKU9. this was below the 90% threshold used for species demarcation. ORFs, and the 5’-UTR and 3’-UTRs are indicated by yellow and grey arrows. the genomic locations of the leader and body TRS(s) are shown with blue and red arrows. subgenomic mRNAs in the sample were probed with a comprehensive set of primers. the PCR products were confirmed on an agarose gel. the lowest band marked with a red arrow on each lane was the specific amplicon from each subgenomic mRNA. the p10 gene of Ro-BatCoV GCCDC1 was transiently expressed in BHK-21 cells as well as the p10 gene of Pulau virus, which was used as a positive control. the alteration of certain conserved amino acids did not impair the syncytiogenesis of p10 gene of Ro-BatCoV GCCDC1. CDC1 with those of avian and bat origin orthoreoviruses, the 28 absolutely conserved amino acids are symbolized with red star. the construction of transient expression plasmid of p10 gene based on a pCAGGS vector. stained monolayers were imaged using an Olympus IX51FL+DP70 microscope under 100 magnification, scale bars = 200 m. the p10 subgenomic mRNA identified in the samples confirmed that the p10 gene could be transcribed from the genome of Ro-BatCoV GCCDC1. however, due to the failure of virus isolation, there is no effective way to judge whether the p10 gene could be expressed during the virus replication cycle. no cell syncytia were observed for all mutant constructs of p10. p10 had substitutions in previously defined key sites in p10 protein of reoviruses. results revealed the expression of p10 by the Ro-BatCoV GCCDC1 virus. the cell lines were inoculated with positive samples. no cytopathic effect was observed in any passage. there was an absence of viral replication from the culture supernatant and cell pellet of each passage. coronavirus is used to show the virus that identified in the present study. the schematic virion of orthoreovirus and the segment S1 of the genome that it contains are used to demonstrate the possible origin of the p10 gene. the genome of Ro-BatCoV GCCDC1 was 30,129 nt in length. NS7a, NS7b and NS7c shared 29% - 53% amino acid identities with the accessory genes of Ro-BatCoV HKU9 strains and other related bat coronaviruses. the encoded protein exhibited 30% - 54.9% amino acid identity with the p10 protein encoded by the first ORF of segment S1 of avian and bat fusogenic orthoreoviruses. NSP12 A4276-Q5207 932 LQ|SV RdRp NSP13 S5207-Q5808 601 TQ|SA HEL, NTPase NSP14 S5809-Q6338 530 LQ|SL ExoN, NMT NSP15 S6339-Q6680 342 LQ|SK NendoU NSP16 S6681-V6973 293 O-MT. the amino acid identities of seven concatenated domains in Ro-BatCoV GCCDC1 revealed that they shared 84.4% - 84.8% identity with those of Ro-BatCoV HKU9. the newly identified Ro-BatCoV GCCDC1 represents a novel coronavirus species in the genus betacoronavirus. GenBank accession numbers: NC_009021, EF065514, EF065515, EF065516, HM211098, HM211099, HM211100, HM211101. to determine the evolutionary position of Ro-BatCoV GCCDC1, the RdRp, S, N and p10 proteins were subjected to phylogenetic analyses. a strikingly different phylogenetic pattern was observed in the distinctive p10 protein (Fig 3), in which the Ro-BatCoV GCCDC1 sequences were clearly related to bat (Pteropine) originated orthoreoviruses. these viruses are clearly more closely related to the bat-origin than avian-origin orthoreoviruses. the integrity and continuity of context sequence surrounding the p10 gene were confirmed with specific primers. the sequence obtained covers, without interruption, the partial N gene, the whole p10 gene and partial NS7a gene. the core sequence of 5’-ACAAAC-3 exhibited a single nucleobase difference to the consensus core sequence (5’-ACAAAC-3’) we also observed a 97 nucleobase sequence between the TRS and the p10 initiation codon (Fig 4B and S2 Fig), which was much longer than the intervening sequences of other genes. the location of TRS in the p10 gene could be discriminated from those of other genes. nine potential subgenomic mRNAs of Ro-BatCoV GCCDC1 were depicted. each lower subgenomic mRNA shared the same 3’-end structure with the upper one to comprise a 3' co-terminal nested set with the genome. the genome is represented by a black line; ORFs. arrow on each lane is the specific amplicon of each subgenomic mRNA. other marked bands are amplicons of upper subgenomic mRNAs. the bias of the TRS of p10 gene is highlighted with a yellow block. the p10 gene of Ro-BatCoV GCCDC1 is functional despite the orthoreovirus origin of p10. the p10 gene of Ro-BatCoV GCCDC1 was transiently expressed in BHK-21 cells as well as the p10 gene of Pulau virus, which was used as a positive control. motifs present in the ectodomain (HP, hydrophobic patch; CM, conserved motif), endodomain (PB, polybasic) and the central transmembrane domain (TMD) are depicted with yellow rectangles. the two cysteines in the ectodomain form an intra-molecular disulfide bond. observation of syncytium formation with recombinant plasmid of p10 gene. recombinant plasmid of p10 subgenome of Ro-BatCoV GCCDC1 and empty pcDNA3.0 vector. p10 subgenomic mRNA identified in the samples confirmed p10 gene could be transcribed from the genome of Ro-BatCoV GCCDC1. p10 protein of GCCDC1 may have the same origin as those of fusogenic orthoreoviruses. no cell syncytia were observed for all mutant constructs of p10. p10 protein was found in bat feces and rectal swab specimens. coV GCCDC1 contains a p10 protein located at the 3’-end of the genome. it appears to have captured from a bat-origin orthoreovirus by heterologous recombination. however, it is also possible that coronaviruses are one of the few virus families that can experience heterologous recombination. the biggest difference between fusogenic and nonfusogenic orthoreoviruses is the presence/absence of a small protein encoded by the segment S1 of the genome. the FAST proteins are the only known nonenveloped reovirus fusogens that can mediate cell-to-cell, but not virus-cell, membrane fusion to induce the formation of syncytia [20], and which might promote the dissemination of virus among cells [37]. the p10 protein enhances the transmission potential of Ro-BatCoV GCCDC1. previous studies of the potential recombination revealed the pivotal role of the shared HE gene for the pathogenesis of betacoronavirus group A. compared to nonfusogenic orthoreoviurses, fusogenic orthoreoviruses can cause severe pneumonia when infecting humans. a similar situation may be observed at the cleavage sites of replicase polyprotein of human coronavirus HKU1 and human coronavirus NL63. a similar situation may be observed at the NSP13/NSP14 cleavage sites of replicase polyprotein of human coronavirus HKU1 and human coronavirus NL63. the protocol in this study was approved by in research of the People's Republic of China. the rectal swab samples were collected and placed in the cryotube with viral transport medium (VTM) containing Earle's balanced salt solution RNA extraction Total RNA was extracted from 100 L of VTM suspension of each swab with the RNeasy Mini Kit (Qiagen, Germany) the RNA was eluted in 60 L AVE buffer, of which 8 L RNA was used as the template for RT-PCR immediately. complete genome sequencing Fresh RNA was extracted from sample numbers 346 and 356 which were confirmed as coronavirus positive. original NGS data were filtered, refined and mapped to the reference sequence of Ro-BatCoV HKU9 (GenBank accession number NC_009021) onavirus HKU1, infectious bronchitis virus, turkey coronavirus, bovine coronavirus, mouse hepatitis virus and porcine epidemic diarrhea virus were used for phylogenetic analyses. the sequences of the 5’ untranslated region (5’-UTR) and 3’ untranslated region (3’-UTR) were defined, and the leader sequence, the leader and body TRSs were illustrated. all amino acid sequence alignments were aligned using MUSCLE [53] and all poorly or ambiguously aligned regions were removed using GBlocks [54] phylogenetic trees of amino acid sequence alignments were inferred using the maximum likelihood method available in the PhyML package [55] each tree was inferred using the maximum likelihood method available in the PhyML package [55], with bootstrap values estimated from 1,000 replicate trees. p10 antiserum production The protein family of the putative p10 protein was analyzed using PFAM [57] and InterProScan [58]. peptides were synthesized after conjugation with keyhole limpet hemocyanin (KLM), followed by boosts until 14 days with the same conjugated peptides. the mice were killed and their blood collected to isolate sera. the p10 gene of Ro-BatCoV GCCDC1 most likely originated in an orthoreovirus. the p10 gene was cloned into the pCAGGS vector and the recombinant plasmid was then transfected into BHK-21 cells using polyethylimine (PEI, Polysciences Inc.) the p10 gene is encoded by the first ORF in segment S1 of the reovirus genome. p10 gene can be transcribed or translated during the replication cycle of GCCDC1. cells transfected with empty pCAGGS vector were used as a mock control. next step is to confirm that p10 can be transcribed or translated. transfected cells were paraformaldehyde-fixed and stained with Wright-Giemsa at the indicated times. pictures were taken at 100 magnification on an Olympus IX51FL+DP70 microscope. original specimens of bat rectal swabs
